childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1991-2003

You were born the year the Soviet Union collapsed and the World Wide Web went public. The Cold War ended before you could walk—the superpower that had defined global politics for seventy years dissolved into fifteen countries before your first birthday. Saddam Hussein became a household name while you were still in diapers, green night-vision footage of Baghdad bombing filling television screens. The defining geopolitical struggle of the twentieth century wrapped up just in time for you to inherit whatever chaos came next.

Your childhood was the last gasp of analog culture before digital consumed everything. You probably had a landline with a cord that stretched just far enough to reach your bedroom, a VCR with a blinking 12:00 nobody knew how to fix, and a Blockbuster membership card with your parents' name on it. Friday nights meant wandering aisles of videotapes, running your fingers across plastic spines, negotiating with siblings, feeling the particular disappointment of your pick being out and the backup choice that sometimes turned out better. Returning tapes on time was a whole responsibility. Late fees were real consequences that taught you deadlines mattered.

The sensory details are specific to your era: the smell of fresh Play-Doh and the distinct non-taste of Elmer's glue, the satisfying click of cassette decks, the weight of a Game Boy with that unlit screen you tilted toward every available light source. You knew the sound of dial-up modems handshaking—that screech and static symphony—and the frustration when someone picked up the phone and killed your connection.

You were six when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel. The adults around you watched her funeral on television, millions mourning someone most had never met. You learned early that grief could be collective, performed, mediated through screens. Ten on 9/11, old enough to remember the day clearly—the confusion, the teachers crying, being sent home early, your parents glued to the television for days. The towers fell on a Tuesday. By Wednesday, American flags were everywhere. By the weekend, nothing felt the same.

Your childhood straddled two eras. You caught the tail end of kids playing outside until streetlights came on, and the beginning of everyone staying inside staring at screens. You're old enough to remember boredom—real boredom, with nothing to scroll through, nothing to stream.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research's definition that finally stuck after years of boundary arguments. Your generation is roughly 72 million people in the US, the largest cohort until Gen Z started surpassing you in recent years.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. You were ten. Fourth or fifth grade. Old enough to remember exactly where you were, what your teacher said, how your parents looked when they picked you up early. Young enough for that morning to fundamentally rewire your sense of safety permanently. The pre-9/11 world is a hazy childhood memory now—airports where families waited at gates, security as formality. Everything after was threat levels, shoe removal, wars that never seemed to end.

Your generation entered adulthood during the 2008 financial crisis. You graduated high school that year, which meant entering college or the workforce as Lehman Brothers collapsed, as the job market cratered, as every adult authority figure admitted they'd been wrong about how the economy worked. The social contract your parents described—work hard, stay loyal, get rewarded with stability and maybe a pension—turned out to be a fairy tale from a different economic era.

Millennials are lodged between Gen X (who got careers and houses before the floor fell out) and Gen Z (who never expected the floor to exist in the first place and adjusted accordingly). You're old enough to remember when the American Dream seemed possible, young enough to know it's not coming back in any recognizable form. That combination of hope and disillusionment is your generational inheritance.

You've been blamed for killing everything from napkins to the diamond industry to casual dining chains. You didn't kill anything—you just couldn't afford it while paying student loans and rent that increased faster than wages.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Nirvana dropped 'Nevermind' and changed music forever. Kurt Cobain in a cardigan, screaming about teen spirit, Butch Vig's production making angst sound radio-friendly—it became the soundtrack for a generation that wasn't yours yet but would define your childhood's ambient noise. By the time you were old enough to appreciate grunge, it was already fading into nostalgia, replaced by boy bands and teen pop.

Film in 1991 gave us 'The Silence of the Lambs,' 'Terminator 2,' and 'Beauty and the Beast.' Serial killers speaking in unsettling riddles, killer robots made of liquid metal, singing teapots—the full range of human emotion and special effects capability. 'Terminator 2' had effects that seemed like magic then and remarkably still hold up now. 'Beauty and the Beast' became the first animated film nominated for Best Picture, proving cartoons could be art.

Television in 1991 launched 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' and 'Home Improvement.' You grew up on Will Smith being effortlessly charming and Tim Allen grunting at power tools—both shows establishing sitcom templates that would dominate your childhood. Sitcoms still had laugh tracks telling you when to react. TV still had appointment viewing. Missing an episode meant waiting for summer reruns or accepting permanent ignorance.

Your childhood was peak Nickelodeon. 'Rugrats' with its baby philosophy and surprisingly dark undertones. 'Doug' with his anxious journal entries and imagined alter ego. 'The Wild Thornberrys' teaching you animal facts. Your middle school years belonged to boy bands, Britney Spears, and TRL counting down videos you'd already seen a hundred times while Carson Daly pointed at screaming crowds. By high school, emo had arrived, and your MySpace profile had a Fall Out Boy song autoplaying to announce your emotional state to anyone who visited.

You consumed pop culture before algorithms decided what you'd see next. You had to seek things out, wait for them, sometimes miss them entirely. Anticipation was real. So was disappointment. Delayed gratification wasn't a choice—it was just how entertainment worked.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Tim Berners-Lee put the World Wide Web online. The internet in 1991 was a research tool for academics and military—nobody predicted cat videos, social media influencers, or the complete rewiring of human attention spans. You arrived just in time to watch it swallow everything.

Linux launched in 1991, which means the operating system running most of the internet's servers is exactly your age. The PowerBook—Apple's first real laptop—debuted the same year. Portable computing was born alongside you. You'd grow up together, technology becoming more portable, more personal, more inescapable with each passing year.

You were four when Windows 95 came out with its Rolling Stones commercial and its revolutionary Start button. Seven when Google launched—lowercase, minimalist, promising not to be evil in ways that would age poorly. Ten when the iPod arrived and carrying a thousand songs in your pocket became possible. Fourteen when Facebook opened to high schoolers. Sixteen when the iPhone dropped and everything before it suddenly looked like antiques.

This makes you one of the last generations to remember life before the internet was inescapable. You know what it's like to be genuinely unreachable—to leave the house and just be gone, no tracking, no check-ins, no constant connectivity. You remember using encyclopedias for homework, the specific texture of library card catalogs, the wait between question and answer.

Your relationship with technology is native but not naturalized. You learned to type on keyboards before touchscreens existed. You remember dial-up modems, AIM away messages crafted like poetry, burning CDs one track at a time. You're fluent in digital but retain muscle memory for analog. That makes you a translator between eras—the last generation that can explain both with authority.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born as the Soviet Union was dying. By December 1991, it was gone—the superpower that had defined global politics for seventy years, that had made your parents' generation practice hiding under desks, dissolved before your first birthday. The Cold War was their existential threat, not yours. Your anxieties would come from different sources: terrorism, economic collapse, climate change, school shootings.

The Gulf War started and ended in your first year of life. Operation Desert Storm filled television screens with green night-vision footage of bombs over Baghdad—the first war broadcast like a video game, complete with graphics packages and theme music. You were too young to see any of it, but it established templates for how America would conduct and consume war for decades.

The Rodney King beating was filmed in March 1991, weeks after your birth. The LA riots erupted the following year, when you were one. The questions those events raised—about police violence, race, justice, and what happens when the system fails people—would keep coming back your entire life, unchanged and unresolved.

You were six when Princess Diana died in Paris. Adults around you watched her funeral on television, grief streaming across faces for someone most had never met. You learned early about parasocial connection, about mourning mediated through screens.

You were eight when Clinton was impeached, ten on 9/11. You remember that day clearly—the confusion, the fear, the teachers trying to explain what they didn't understand themselves. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started soon after. You grew up during wartime, though the wars were far away and mostly invisible, filtered through evening news segments that rarely showed consequences.

You were seventeen during the 2008 financial crisis, watching your parents' retirement accounts collapse, watching foreclosure signs appear on neighbors' lawns, watching the economy that was supposed to support you crater just as you were preparing to enter it. By twenty-four, marriage equality was law. By twenty-five, Trump was president. By twenty-nine, a global pandemic. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than you can count, each arriving before you'd recovered from the last.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated high school in 2009, directly into the worst job market since the Great Depression. College, if you went, was a four-year holding pattern while the economy theoretically recovered. It didn't fully recover—not for entry-level workers, not for years. You graduated college around 2013, into a job market that had improved from catastrophic to merely terrible.

Your generation perfected the unpaid internship as entry point, the gig economy as safety net, the LinkedIn profile optimized for algorithms that might—might—show it to someone who could help. You learned to describe yourself in corporate jargon: 'passionate self-starter,' 'results-driven team player,' 'dynamic problem-solver.' You learned to care performatively about the mission of companies that would lay you off without warning.

You're the generation that stopped expecting loyalty from employers because employers stopped offering it first. Pensions disappeared before you entered the workforce—relics from your grandparents' era. Raises became 'we're all tightening our belts' speeches delivered by executives who'd just received bonuses. Job-hopping became survival strategy rather than character flaw. You learned to leave before being left.

You've worked in offices with beer fridges and 'unlimited PTO' policies that punish anyone who actually uses them. You've sat through performance reviews where exceeding expectations earned cost-of-living adjustments that didn't match actual cost of living increases. You've been told you're 'like family' by employers who'd fire you by Slack message if it helped quarterly numbers.

COVID normalized remote work, proving you could do your job from anywhere without micromanagement. The downside: employers now expect you to be available everywhere, all the time. The boundary between work and life dissolved. You didn't work from home—you lived at work, bedroom and office merged into one fluorescent-free but somehow still exhausting space.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that watched dating transform from analog ritual to digital algorithm. Tinder launched when you were twenty-two—young enough to adopt it as natural evolution, old enough to remember meeting people through proximity and chance. Swiping became the new exchanging numbers at parties. You've probably dated someone you met through an app, which your parents find bewildering and Gen Z finds completely unremarkable.

You communicate primarily through text, but you remember when phone calls were normal—when actually hearing someone's voice was the default rather than reserved for emergencies and parents. You know the anxiety of waiting for a response, the micro-analysis of punctuation choices, the different implications of 'ok' versus 'okay' versus 'OK' versus 'k.' You've conducted entire relationships through screens, wondering somewhere in the back of your mind if that counts.

Your generation delayed marriage longer than any before. Not because you don't want partnership, but because weddings cost money you don't have, houses cost more, children cost even more than that. The life timeline your parents followed required economic conditions that no longer exist. You're not commitment-averse—you're priced out of the milestones that signal commitment.

You've maintained long-distance friendships through group chats and video calls because everyone moved—for jobs, for cheaper rent, for somewhere that seemed like it might offer more. You've watched relationships form and dissolve on social media. You've learned to be close to people you rarely see in person and performatively close to people you see all the time. The difference between online connection and real connection got blurry somewhere along the way.

Ghosting became a dating phenomenon during your years. So did 'situationships' and 'talking stages' and every other non-committal terminology for relationships that aren't quite relationships. You've had to invent vocabulary for dynamics previous generations didn't have to navigate, because the technology changed the dynamics faster than language could keep up.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were ten during the dot-com crash—abstract at the time, something adults worried about while you worried about fifth grade. Seventeen during the 2008 financial crisis, which was not abstract at all. Senior year of high school, watching the economy collapse, watching your plans for the future become suddenly uncertain. Twenty-nine during the COVID economic collapse. You've watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. This tends to produce a financial worldview somewhere between calculated pessimism and outright paranoia.

Your relationship with money is defined by scarcity that keeps getting worse no matter what you do. You probably have student loan debt that will follow you for decades. Housing prices have tripled since you were a teenager. The math doesn't work—it hasn't worked for years—but you keep trying anyway because the alternative is giving up entirely, and giving up doesn't pay rent.

You save when you can because you've seen how fast stability disappears. One job loss, one medical emergency, one economic crisis can erase years of careful budgeting. You invest reluctantly because you don't trust the stock market after watching it crater repeatedly, but you don't trust Social Security to exist when you're seventy either, so you're hedging bets on systems that might not survive. You're playing a game rigged against you because not playing means losing by default.

You've been lectured about financial responsibility by generations who bought houses for less than your annual rent costs. 'Stop buying lattes,' they say, as if $5 a day adds up to a $400,000 down payment. The American Dream of upward mobility became a punchline in your lifetime.

Your generation is redefining financial success because the old definition is unattainable. Success isn't homeownership—it's affording rent without roommates in a city where the jobs are. Success isn't retiring at 65—it's having enough to stop working before your body gives out completely. Success isn't leaving an inheritance—it's not becoming a burden to your kids, if you have them, if you can afford them.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is mistaking awareness for action. You're extremely good at identifying problems—systemic racism, climate change, economic inequality, institutional rot. You can articulate them eloquently in threads and infographics and think pieces. You're less good at the boring, grinding work of actually fixing them. Sharing an infographic isn't organizing. A hashtag isn't a movement. You sometimes confuse performance of caring with actual participation in change.

You've gotten so used to broken systems that you've stopped questioning whether they should exist at all. You've normalized healthcare tied to employment as if that arrangement makes any sense. You've accepted that education requires decades of debt as if that's inevitable rather than a policy choice. You've treated retirement as a fantasy rather than a failure of social contract. You've learned to cope with dysfunction instead of demanding structural change. Adaptability became resignation wearing a self-deprecating smile.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be collaborative, to not make waves, to bring solutions instead of problems. This makes you easy to exploit professionally. You'll work unpaid overtime for 'experience.' You'll accept equity instead of salary because 'we're a startup, we're all in this together.' You'll stay in toxic situations because leaving feels like personal failure and the job market is brutal and you need health insurance that only comes with employment.

Your irony and self-deprecation sometimes block earnest advocacy. You can't just care about something—you have to care about it with defensive layers, with qualifications, with humor that undercuts before anyone else can. This makes it hard to demand what you actually want without hedging. Sincerity feels dangerous. Advocacy feels cringe. You protect yourself from vulnerability by never being fully vulnerable.

You're so online that you sometimes forget offline is where real stakes live. You can mobilize millions of views on social media, but voter turnout among your generation still lags. You can cancel celebrities, but changing zoning policy requires showing up to school board meetings nobody watches. The digital feels like power. It usually isn't.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2011-2021): You entered adulthood during economic recovery that never quite reached entry-level workers. Jobs required experience you couldn't get without jobs—the catch-22 that defined your cohort's early careers. You probably lived with roommates, or parents, or both at different points. You delayed everything the previous generation did in their twenties—marriage, kids, homeownership—because the economics made those milestones impossible on your salary. Your twenties were supposed to be exploratory and formative. They were mostly just expensive.

Your 30s (2021-2031): You're in this decade now, a pandemic marking its beginning like a grim welcome mat. You're probably earning more than at twenty-five, but inflation ate most of the gains before you could invest them. You're watching younger people enter the workforce and older people retire while you're stuck in the middle, too established to start over, too financially precarious to relax. This is the decade where you're supposed to have figured things out. You haven't. Nobody has. That's the secret nobody tells you until you're already here.

Your 40s (2031-2041): Statistically, this will be your peak earning decade. You'll have more professional authority, more clarity about what matters, more peace with what you can't change. If you have kids, they'll be getting older, developing into their own complicated people. Your parents will be aging, which brings responsibilities you haven't fully anticipated and can't entirely plan for. You'll be managing everyone else's needs while your own get scheduled around the edges. This is the decade where you either commit to the life you've built or blow it up and rebuild from scratch while you still have the energy.

Your 50s (2041-2051): By now, you'll have lived through at least four major economic crises, probably a couple more pandemics, and countless 'unprecedented' events that arrive every few years. You'll be pre-retirement age but retirement won't be financially possible for most of your cohort. You'll mentor younger workers who don't understand your scars, who can't imagine a world before smartphones. You'll catch yourself sounding like the older generations you used to mock, and you'll hate how familiar that feels.

Your 60s and beyond (2051+): Retirement, if it exists, won't look like your grandparents' retirement—the pension, the decades of leisure, the gold watch. It'll be part-time work, gig economy income, or dependence on kids who are struggling themselves. Climate change will have reshaped geography. Technology will have changed in ways nobody can predict. You'll explain to younger people what life was like before the internet was everywhere, before AI was embedded in everything. They won't quite believe you. The world will look nothing like the one you were born into.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.1 million people born in 1991.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You're more educated, more diverse, and significantly less wealthy at the same age. Gen X entered a functioning economy where degrees paid off and loyalty was rewarded. You entered the wreckage. They got affordable college tuition—actual affordable, not 'we have payment plans' affordable. You got student loans that follow you for decades. They got pensions and stable employment. You got '1099 contractor' arrangements with no benefits and 'unlimited PTO' policies that punish anyone who uses them.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is staggering. Boomers controlled 21% of national wealth when they were your age. Millennials control about 7%. Boomers bought houses for what you pay in annual rent. Boomers retired with pensions and Social Security they'll collect for decades. You're hoping those programs still exist when you're old enough to qualify, and the math isn't reassuring.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're similar in values but arrived at cynicism from different directions. You remember when things seemed like they could work out—when optimism felt rational. Gen Z doesn't have that memory; they were born into aftermath. You believed the system was fixable through reform. They assume it's broken and are building workarounds instead. You adapted to smartphones in your teens. They were born into them. You're the last generation with clear memories of before the internet consumed everything.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol-related deaths. Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before. More anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world you were promised and the world you received turned out to be very different things.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before you. You've normalized therapy, destigmatized mental health struggles, pushed for equity in ways your parents' generation didn't prioritize. You've made the world more inclusive even as it became less affordable. That contradiction is your generational legacy—progress and precarity, hope and evidence, all tangled together.

year_events: Soviet Union collapsed into fifteen countries
Gulf War ended with liberation of Kuwait
